title: Rugby World Cup semi-final: How can England beat New Zealand?
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

England arrived in Yokohama in justifiably confident mood ahead of their Rugby World Cup semi-final against the All Blacks following last weekend’s ultimately convincing win over Australia.

Eddie Jones’ side largely kept their powder dry during the group stage and benefited from the two-week break Typhoon Hagibis afforded them to produce, by some distance, their most cohesive performance of the tournament so far and recording a 40-16 win over the Wallabies.

The England head coach sprung something of a surprise with his team selection on Thursday by recalling George Ford and shunting Owen Farrell back to centre after the latter had dictated the game so effectively in his preferred position last week.

Advertisement

Advertisement

New Zealand, meanwhile, look in typically imperious form having amassed 203 points from their four fixtures so far and swatted Ireland aside last weekend, running in seven tries.

England’s previous World Cup semi-final encounter with New Zealand back in 1995 saw the All Blacks, inspired by Jonah Lomu, storm to a 45-29 win and it would represent a huge upset were England to prevent Steve Hansen’s side from winning an unprecedented third successive World Cup.

A host of former England players, however, believe a win is possible and here’s how they could pull it off…

Will Greenwood: Win the kicking game

Owen Farrell’s kicking game must be spot on against New Zealand (Picture: Getty)

‘For England to beat New Zealand, their kicking game must be perfect,’ said Will Greenwood, England second highest ever try scorer, told the Daily Telegraph.

‘We like to think the World Cup will be won by free-flowing, all-court ball handling. The reality is that most of the best handling phases and chances to score tries will emanate from kicks, kick chases or kick pressure.

‘If a team does not handle all the points around its kicking game and its kick defence then they will lose the territory battle, will come under pressure and almost certainly lose.’

Matt Dawson: Discipline is essential

‘It starts with individual performance,’ Dawson, the man who provided the pass from which Jonny Wilkinson kicked the drop goal that won England the 2003 World Cup, told the BBC.

‘The front row, Maro Itoje and Owen Farrell are world class. Billy Vunipola, Ben Youngs, Manu Tuilagi and Elliot Daly must step up to that level. Tom Curry and Sam Underhill have got to obliterate the opposition.

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘And then England have got to assume that they make no mistakes at the weekend – no offsides, no penalties, nothing. They have got to play the perfect game.’

Brian Moore: Limit Beauden Barrett’s running opportunities

Beauden Barrett represents one of New Zealand’s main dangermen with ball in hand (Picture: Getty)

‘England have more ball carriers and more line breakers than even South Africa or Wales with their tenacity. I think that is in their favour, and if they do take chances they obviously have to take them.

‘But this is the point for me and it has been hit and miss with England for a while, their kicking game has to be absolutely spot on.

‘If you give their back field runners inspired by Barrett, you know you’re talking no end of pace, but also intelligence, if your’e not spot on with that then they’ll cut you to shreds.

Paul Grayson: Deal with Scott Barrett at the line-out

Scott Barrett represents a huge threat to England’s potential line-out supremacy (Picture: Getty)

‘Picking Scott Barrett, a lock, at blind-side flanker is a huge call from Hansen – and a brilliant one potentially,’ the former fly-half, third on the list of England’s all-time points scorers, told the BBC.

‘I did not even consider it but it is his tactical opener. England lock Courtney Lawes has now got a massive job on his hands.

‘New Zealand have got four genuine line-out options: Barrett, Brodie Retallick, Sam Whitelock and Kieran Read.

Advertisement

‘England have got two options: Lawes and Maro Itoje – maybe two and a half because Tom Curry might be able to win a line-out.

‘England have picked a team to play quick. But if you cannot win your set-piece and the All Blacks keep knocking the ball off the pitch then it is going to be really difficult.’

George Chuter: Make it a physical battle

Sam Underhill and Mako Vunipola possess the physical power to unsettle New Zealand (Picture: Getty)

‘It’s the same every time you play the all-blacks you’ve got to be mistake free which is why it’s so difficult to beat them,’ said the former England hooker. ‘To play someone for 80 minutes in test rugby and not make a mistake is tough.

‘Some of the silly penalties that actually England seemed to have dried up in their quarter final, we can’t have any of them.

‘We can’t be having silly turnovers you have got to execute everything, and on top of that you have got to be quick and aggressive around the field.

‘The teams that beat them, Ireland beat them recently, out-muscled them physically and got on top of them. And once you get on top of them you have to keep them down and really stick your foot on their neck.’
